Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of a GC/MS triple quadrupole for the characterization of terrestrial plant biomarkers in complex environmental media at TAMUG
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).
This award will fund the acquisition of a gas chromatography triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (CG-TQ-MS/MS), an electron multiplier, and an oxidation system. These instruments will support research on 2 major topics, 1) the transfer of terrigenous organic matter (TOM) from watersheds to aquatic systems in both dissolved and particulate forms and 2) the impact of biomass combustion on air quality in urban and rural settings. Such transport is strongly dependent on hydrological processes in the watershed with short-lived flood events playing a substantial role in large-scale pulse transfers. The PIs will investigate how hydrological shifts predicted by climate change scenarios may impact the overall transport of natural organic matter in natural and perturbed (e.g. urban) watersheds. The Arctic project is also introducing lignin as an additional tracer for upper Arctic Ocean ventilation processes in order to reconcile recently observed discrepancies among other established oceanographic tracers. In particular, TOM tracers will help to identify the different components of the Arctic freshwater cycle. The GC/MS will also contribute analytical capacity to recent research at TAMUG in characterizing the composition of combustion-derived particles depositing over urban to rural watersheds. Biomass combustion is a major source of atmospheric particles that affect air quality at the local to regional scale and climate at the regional to global scale. Climate fluctuations, and in particular changes in drought cyclicity and intensity are strong drivers of wildfire events which themselves contribute substantially to atmospheric aerosol loads.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The new instrumentation was targeted to enhance the undergraduate training at TAMUG and to provide additional instrumental capacity to support a series of funded projects, including the NSF-REU program recently awarded to TAMUG, an NSF Arctic research project (awarded to Dr. Amon), and a recent project (partly funded by rapid NSF funds) assessing the impact of the BP Deep Water Horizon oil spill on benthic communities of the northern Gulf of Mexico. In the seven months since its installation (August 2010), the new GC/MS Triple Quadrupole (TQMS) system supported a series of projects performed by both undergraduate and graduate students. In the summer of 2010, in the firs few months of the instrument’s installation, two undergraduate students joined Dr. Louchouarn’s group as part of TAMUG’s NSF-REU program to recruit students from underserved and underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines. Both students worked on the characterization of dissolved and particulate matter in river and ocean samples using both an older GC/MS ion trap and the new GC/TQMS. This work allowed us to demonstrate the presence of fire biomarkers in particulate matter in open ocean systems demonstrating the long residence time of these terrestrially-derived organic compounds in aquatic systems and thus their potential to trace fire events over large scales of space and time. In the fall, the new instrument was also used in a research project performed in a newly developed upper level undergraduate class in Quantitative Chemistry and Instrumental Analysis at TAMUG. The project was further developed into a senior thesis as a partial requirement to the completion of a student’s Honor Undergraduate Research Scholars (UGR) program at Texas A&M University. Additional funds supported this work in the form of a Fellowship from the Welch Foundation. The results of this project were presented at the 241st National Meeting of the American Chemical Society, and will be the subject of a publication to be written and submitted in the summer of 2011. This new course in Quantitative Chemistry can thus serve as an example of educational material that can be based on authentic inquiry approaches and lead to authentic scholarship.

 

At the graduate level, the new instrumentation supported a PhD student’s work from Dr. Rob Griffin’s lab (Rice University, Dept. of Civil and Environmental Engineering). This collaboration provided analytical capacity towards the characterization of potential biogenic sources of primary aerosols in the atmosphere of a major U.S. urban system (Houston, TX). The high sensitivity of the GC/TQMS permitted the detection of plant and combustion biomass biomarkers in extremely small sample sizes (ug). This work was part of the student’s last chapter of his dissertation and will be submitted in April 2011 as a manuscript and presented at the annual American Association for Aerosol Research. The student defended successfully his PhD Dissertation on March 28, 2011. In addition, Dr. Louchouarn continued hosting a young PhD candidate from the Virginia Institute of Marine Sciences who is doing research with Dr. Liz Canuel on the impact of land use and fire events on carbon fluxes to and out of freshwater reservoirs in California. Her preliminary work was presented in 2010 at the 6th Biennial Bay-Delta Science Conference. Finally, as stated in the proposal the NSF-MRI grant permitted an upgrade of the older GCMS ion trap, which provides the right analytical capability to work the recent project assessing the impact of the BP oil spill. Total petroleum hydrocarbon and PAHs are measured using this instrument.
